pages.title: Welcome to the L.I.C.H. Rulebook
body: L.I.C.H. is a tactical board & card game played on a hex grid with heroes (Avatars), summons, surfaces, and source-driven cards.
Readability tip: Each numbered rule is linkable; hover the link icon to copy a direct URL.

figures.caption: High-level components of L.I.C.H.
figures.alt: Overview diagram of board zones, avatars, and action zones

rules.text: The game uses a hexagonal board with a hex grid; each side has 6 hexes.
Starting positions are the six corners of the board.
Source Stones are placed on the board before play.
When an Avatar occupies a Source Stone tile, its controller must draw 1 pure source if able.
Summons treat Source Stones as walls except for line of sight.
Source Stones do not impede line of sight.
Avatars and Summons may not occupy wall tiles.
Walls block line of sight.
Walls are placed according to map setup before play.
Avatars represent their controller’s hero on the board.
Summon pieces come in pairs of matching design or color.
One piece marks the summoned target on the board and the other marks its summoning card, linking them.
Surface tiles are placed on the board to represent the surface occupying that tile.
Each player has a field containing their cards and deck.
The action zone consists of 5 action slots.
Each slot may hold one action card.
The action zone is public knowledge at all times.
The deck is where cards are drawn from, especially at the end of each turn.
The deck is kept face down and not freely searchable.
Destroyed, discarded, or attrited cards go to the controller’s Purgatory.
All purgatories are public knowledge at all times.
Damned or offered cards go to the controller’s Abyss.
All abysses are public knowledge at all times.
The Hero zone holds a player's Hero card.
All Hero zones are public knowledge at all times.
Each player’s hand is private to non‑teammates.

figures.caption: Board with corners, zones, and example walls.
figures.alt: Hex board with marked corners and zones

rules.text: The board is set up according to the to-be-played map.
Base Offering: Each player draws 3, chooses 1 to offer (face‑down), then reveal. Highest total source cost goes first; turn order clockwise.
Tie breaker: Tied players reshuffle, redraw 3, choose again; reveal and compare.
Sudden Death: If still tied, tied players reveal cards from top of deck until a winner emerges.
End of Offering: The chosen card is put into its controller’s Abyss; all other cards are shuffled back. Players do not draw initial hands yet.
In turn order, each player picks an Avatar and places it on a starting corner.
Initial hands are drawn after Avatars are placed.
Return your entire hand to your deck, redraw that many cards, then discard 1 card for each mulligan after the first.
After all players have drawn their hands and finished Mulligans, the game begins.
Start Phase: Untap all tapped cards and used AP.

Main Phase: In any order, multiple times—move up to 2 tiles; play/activate cards/effects as affordable; play 1 Source card. Alternatively, you may offer any number of cards to the Lich (damn them) and immediately go to Status Phase.
Status Phase: Resolve statuses; then resolve Death Fog.

End Phase: Draw up to max hand size; lose 2 health per card above max; place 1 Death Fog tile on the outermost unobstructed ring (not on walls or existing Death Fog). If walls inside a complete layer break, the opening fills with Death Fog.

figures.caption: Turn loop and Death Fog expansion.
figures.alt: Circular diagram of phases with a ring for Death Fog

rules.text: Each player has 2 AP, refreshed at the Start Phase.
Tap effects may be used at reaction speed for 1 AP, or at technique speed during your turn for 1 AP.

Blocking: Equipment with ≥1 defense can block damage to an Avatar. If incoming damage ≥ defense, all damage is prevented and the equipment is destroyed. If incoming damage < defense, no damage is dealt. Blocking requires tapping the equipment.
Damage is only 'dealt' when it successfully reduces health of a target.
An attack is any action that hinders movement, reduces health/defense, or applies statuses to a target.
To target with a card, your Avatar must have line of sight (LoS). LoS lines start at the center of the origin tile and extend through faces/vertices.
LoS is blocked when a line meets the center of a wall tile or the edge between consecutive wall tiles; Avatars and Summons also block LoS.
Targets can be cards (controller must be in valid LoS), Avatars, Summons, tiles, walls, surfaces, and all field zones.

figures.caption: Line-of-sight examples with walls and units.
figures.alt: Hex grid with rays showing blocked vs valid LoS

rules.text: A Hero's Intelligence is shown by the number in front of the brain symbol on the Hero card.
Intelligence equals the player's max hand size.
Intelligence is the player's max range for targeting in line of sight.
A Hero’s starting Health is the number in front of the heart symbol on the Hero card.
Health decreases when damage is dealt to the Hero's Avatar.
If a Hero’s Health is 0 or less, that player loses and is removed from play.

pages.title: Hero Effect
body: Heroes may have an accompanying effect which may be played at any time unless otherwise stated. Their effect is described on their Hero card.

pages.title: Death
body: If a player dies, all of their cards are removed from play immediately, even if they are in play by other players or elsewhere than their field.

rules.text: Card effects can override written rules.
Card effects describe additional ways cards can influence the game state.
Card effects use keywords to represent pre-defined actions.
Card effects may have a cost associated with them.
The cost is all actions to the left of the effect’s colon (e.g., 'Pay 10 Health : Deal 10 damage to target').
The cost of an effect must be paid before the effect is performed.
Tap a card.
Cards may either be tapped or untapped.
You may not tap an already tapped card.
Tapped cards untap during their controller’s Start phase.
Untap a card.
Remove an in-play card from the field and send it to its controller’s Purgatory.
Apply a status.
See section 'Blocking | Dealing Damage'.
Gain an amount of Health.
Put a surface on a valid tile.
Invalid tiles include those occupied by walls or Death Fog.
Change position along adjacent, unoccupied tiles a number of times.
Moving 0 tiles still creates a reactable movement event.
Place the top card of your deck into your hand.
Prevent a reactable game state change.
Take the top card of a player's deck and place it into their Purgatory.
Take a card from the controller’s hand and place it into the Purgatory.
Send a card to the controller’s Abyss.

pages.title: Card Source Cost
body: Non-source cards have an associated source cost to play. The source cost is shown by the numbers in front of the colored orbs at the top of a card. Players must have the available source to pay this cost before playing the card.

rules.text: When source is granted to a player, it is placed into their source pool.
A player's source pool empties at the start of each turn.
All source in the pool is available for card effects and paying source costs.

pages.title: Action Cards
body: All action cards occupy one of a player's five action zone slots and are played from hand during the controller's Main phase.

rules.text: Equipment cards are a type of Action card.
Equipment cards have a defense value signified by the shield symbol.
The defense value of equipment is used when blocking.
Summon cards are a type of Action card.
When played, matching summon pieces are placed on the card and the occupied tile.
The shield value of the card is the Summon's Health.
If a Summon's Health is 0 or less, remove the Summon and destroy its summoning card, removing both pieces from play.
A Summon's Health regenerates during every player's Start phase.
Skill cards are a type of Action card.
Skill cards accumulate counters over time.
Effects on a Skill card unlock when the required number of counters is reached (e.g., '[3] Tap : Deal 5 Damage to Target').
Alterations are neither Action cards nor Tactic cards.
Alterations modify other cards.
An altered card is modified based on the alteration's effect.
Techniques are a type of Tactic card.
Techniques may be played from hand during the player's Main phase.
Reactions are a type of Tactic card.
Reactions may be played after a reactable event within line of sight.
Not reactable events include: source played or tapped, Death Fog placed, statuses resolved, phase changes, drawing cards, targets destroyed, and offering to the Lich.
Pure Sources tap for only one source of one type.
Non-Pure Sources tap for more than one of a type or include additional effects.

pages.title: Overview
body: Once cards or effects are played or activated, their effects resolve on a 'first in, last out' stack order.

rules.text: The Stack resolves effects in first-in, last-out order.

pages.title: Fizzling
body: A card 'fizzles' when its effect cannot fully resolve; the cost is still paid but no part of the fizzled effect resolves.

rules.text: Fizzled effects do not resolve, but their costs remain paid.
Technique cards are played at technique speed by default.
Cards played at technique speed cannot add to an existing stack and always create their own stack.
All effects and cards are played at reaction speed by default unless otherwise specified.
Cards played at reaction speed may add to existing stacks or create their own independent stacks.

Example: Player one taps equipment to deal 5 damage; Player two responds with 'negate an incoming attack'. Player two's effect resolves first, negating the attack and causing the first effect to fizzle.

pages.title: Overview
body: Modifiers are keywords that alter the card abilities.

pages.title: Overview
body: Statuses are inflicted onto targets, changing their behavior. Inflicted statuses are signified by status counters placed onto the afflicted targets.

rules.text: Line of sight does not stop at Avatars or Summons.
Multiple targets along the same line of sight may be targeted.
Allows a card's Tap effect to resolve multiple separate consecutive times for a single AP.
If incoming damage is blocked, any damage above the amount blocked is still dealt.
Invisible targets may only be targeted from adjacent tiles.
A blind target may only target adjacent targets.
A burning target is dealt 5 damage during its status phase.
You may not move.
If inflicted with Burning, remove an equal number of Wet and Burning counters.
If inflicted with Sepsis, remove an equal number of Wet and Sepsis counters.
You must spend 1 AP per tile moved.
On Death Fog during Status Phase, your health becomes zero and you may not heal.
This loss of health is not damage and the status is non-removable via card effects.
On Death Fog during Status Phase, lose half your remaining health, rounded up.
At the end of your status phase, remove Impending Doom and inflict Lich’s Curse.
You may not heal; this loss is not damage and is non-removable via card effects.
A stunned target may not play cards or activate abilities at reaction speed, including reactions.
A stunned target may activate abilities at technique speed.
A stunned target cannot block.
Tap abilities are now at technique speed.
The inflicting player controls all movement of a possessed Avatar or Summon.
Possessed status is tracked with paired possession counters placed on the possessor and the possessed.

pages.title: Overview
body: Surfaces occupy tiles, adding effects to the tile. If a surface is placed on an already surfaced tile, the preceding surface is removed unless otherwise stated. Surfaces apply their status the moment a target is within the surface.

rules.text: Surfaces may not be placed on Death Fog.
Death Fog overrides all other surfaces when placed.
Inflicts Impending Doom to occupying targets.
Death Fog may not be removed or destroyed once placed.
Inflicts Burning 1 to occupying targets during the status phase.
When placed on Water, Steam is placed instead.
Inflicts Sepsis 2 to occupying target during the status phase.
Blocks line of sight.
Inflicts Ensnared to occupying targets.
If adjacent to a fire surface at the start of a status phase, convert to a fire surface.
Vines have 1 HP and are destroyed when reduced to 0.
When placed on Fire, Steam is placed instead.
Inflicts Wet to occupying targets.
Steam does nothing.
Smoke blocks line of sight to preceding tiles.
Smoke does not block line of sight to its own tile.
Smoke inflicts blindness 1 to occupying targets.

keywords.name: Tap
keywords.definition: Change a card to tapped; you cannot tap an already tapped card; tapped cards untap during their controller’s Start Phase.

keywords.name: Destroy
keywords.definition: Remove an in‑play card and send it to its controller’s Purgatory.

keywords.name: Deal
keywords.definition: See Blocking/Dealing Damage rules for how damage is considered 'dealt'.

keywords.name: Place
keywords.definition: Put a surface on a valid tile (not walls, not Death Fog).

keywords.name: Move
keywords.definition: Change position along adjacent unoccupied tiles up to the stated amount; moving 0 still creates a reactable movement event.

keywords.name: Draw
keywords.definition: Move the top card of your deck into your hand.

keywords.name: Negate
keywords.definition: Prevent a reactable game state change.

keywords.name: Attrit
keywords.definition: Put the top card of a player’s deck into their Purgatory.

keywords.name: Discard
keywords.definition: Put a card from hand into Purgatory.

keywords.name: Damn
keywords.definition: Send a card to its controller’s Abyss.

statuses.name: Penetrate
effects: LoS does not stop at Avatars or Summons; multiple targets along one LoS line may be targeted.

statuses.name: Reprise
effects: Allows a card’s Tap effect (if any) to resolve multiple separate consecutive times for a single AP.

statuses.name: Overwhelm
effects: If blocked, excess damage beyond the block is still dealt to the original target.

statuses.name: Invisible
effects: May only be targeted from adjacent tiles.

statuses.name: Wet
effects: If inflicted with Burning, remove an equal number of Wet and Burning counters; if inflicted with Sepsis, remove an equal number of Wet and Sepsis counters.

statuses.name: Sepsis
effects: You must spend 1 AP per tile moved.

statuses.name: Lich’s Curse
effects: If on a Death Fog tile during Status Phase, health becomes 0; you may not heal; this loss is not 'damage'; cannot be removed by card effects.

statuses.name: Impending Doom
effects: If on Death Fog during Status Phase: lose half your remaining health (rounded up); then remove Impending Doom and inflict Lich’s Curse; you may not heal; this loss is not 'damage'; non‑removable by effects.

statuses.name: Stunned
effects: May not play/activate at reaction speed; may use technique-speed; cannot block; Tap abilities are now technique-speed.

statuses.name: Possessed
effects: Inflictor controls movement of the possessed Avatar or Summon; tracked via paired possession counters on the possessor/possessed.

surfaces.name: Death Fog
properties: Cannot place other surfaces on Death Fog; overrides all other surfaces; inflicts Impending Doom to occupants; cannot be removed/destroyed once placed.

surfaces.name: Fire
properties: When placed on Water, becomes Steam.

surfaces.name: Vines
properties: If adjacent to Fire at the start of a Status Phase, converts to Fire
Has 1 HP and can be destroyed at 0

surfaces.name: Water
properties: When placed on Fire, becomes Steam.

surfaces.name: Smoke
properties: Blocks LoS to preceding tiles but not to its own tile.
